sp.p: Why, there it is; he has no money, that's true; but then, as he never ſaid no to any requeſt in his life, he has given them a bill drawn by a friend of his upon a merchant in the city, which I am to get chang'd; for you muſt know that I am to go with them to Scotland myſelf.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: How!

sp.speaker: Jarvis.
sp.p: It ſeems the young gentleman is obliged to take a different road from his miſtreſs, as he is to call upon an uncle of his that lives out of the way, in order to prepare a place for their reception, when they return; ſo they have borrowed me from my maſter, as the propereſt perſon to attend the young lady down.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: To the land of matrimony! A pleaſant journey, Jarvis.

sp.speaker: Jarvis.
sp.p: Ay, but I'm only to have all the fatigues on't.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p:
Well, it may be ſhorter, leſs fatiguing, than you imagine. I know but too much of the young lady's family and connexions, whom I have
ſeen abroad. I have alſo diſcover'd that Miſs Richland is not indifferent to my thoughtleſs nephew; and he endeavours, tho' I fear, in vain, to eſtabliſh that connexion. But, come, the letter I wait for muſt be almoſt finiſh'd; I'll let you further into my intentions, in the next room.

div.head: ACT THE FOURTH.

sp.speaker: Lofty.
sp.p: Well, ſure the devil's in me of late, for running my head into ſuch defiles, as nothing but a genius like my own could draw me from. I was formerly contented to huſband out my places and penſions with ſome degree of frugality; but, curſe it, of late I have given away the whole Court Regiſter in leſs time than they could print the title page; yet, hang it, why ſcruple a lie or two to come at a fine girl, when I every day tell a thouſand for nothing. Ha! Honeywood here before. Could Miſs Richland have ſet him at liberty?

Mr. Honeywood, I'm glad to ſee you abroad again. I find my concurrence was not neceſſary in your unfortunate affairs. I had put things in a train to do your buſineſs; but it is not for me to ſay what I intended doing.

sp.speaker: Honeyw.
sp.p: It was unfortunate indeed, Sir. But what adds to my uneaſineſs is, that while you ſeem to be acquainted with my misfortune, I, myſelf, continue ſtill a ſtranger to my benefactor.

sp.speaker: Lofty.
sp.p: How! not know the friend that ſerved you?

sp.speaker: Honeyw.
sp.p: Can't gueſs at the perſon.

sp.speaker: Lofty.
sp.p: Enquire.

sp.speaker: Honeyw.
sp.p: I have, but all I can learn is, that he chuſes to remain concealed, and that all enquiry muſt be fruitleſs.

sp.speaker: Lofty.
sp.p: Muſt be fruitleſs?

sp.speaker: Honeyw.
sp.p: Abſolutely fruitleſs.

sp.speaker: Lofty.
sp.p: Sure of that?

sp.speaker: Honyw.
sp.p: Very ſure.

sp.speaker: Lofty.
sp.p: Then I'll be damn'd if you ſhall ever know it from me.

sp.speaker: Honeyw.
sp.p: How, Sir!

sp.speaker: Lofty.
sp.p: I ſuppoſe now, Mr. Honeywood, you think my rent-roll very conſiderable, and that I have vaſt ſums of money to throw away; I know you do. The world to be ſure ſays ſuch things of me.

sp.speaker: Honeyw.
sp.p: The world, by what I learn, is no ſtranger to your generoſity But where does this tend?

sp.speaker: Lofty.
sp.p: To nothing; nothing in the world. The town, to be ſure, when it makes ſuch a thing as me the ſubject of converſation, has aſſerted, that I never yet patronized a man of merit.

sp.speaker: Honeyw.
sp.p: I have heard inſtances to the contrary, even from yourſelf.

sp.speaker: Lofty.
sp.p: Yes, Honeywood, and there are inſtances to the contrary, that you ſhall never hear from myſelf.

sp.speaker: Honeyw.
sp.p: Ha, dear Sir, permit me to aſk you but one queſtion.

sp.speaker: Lofty.
sp.p: Sir, aſk me no queſtions: I ſay, Sir, aſk me no queſtions; I'll be damn'd, if I anſwer them.

sp.speaker: Honeyw.
sp.p: I will aſk no further. My friend, my benefactor, it is, it muſt be here, that I am indebted for freedom, for honour. Yes, thou worthieſt of men, from the beginning I ſuſpected it, but was afraid to return thanks; which, if undeſerved, might ſeem reproaches.

sp.speaker: Lofty.
sp.p: I proteſt I don't underſtand all this, Mr. Honeywood. You treat me very cavalierly. I do aſſure you, Sir.—Blood, Sir, can't a man be permitted to enjoy the luxury of his own feelings without all this parade?

sp.speaker: Honeyw.
sp.p: Nay, do not attempt to conceal an action that adds to your honour. Your looks, your air, your manner, all confeſs it.

sp.speaker: Lofty.
sp.p:
Confeſs it! Sir. Torture itſelf, Sir, ſhall never bring me to confeſs it. Mr. Honeywood, I have admitted you upon terms of friendſhip. Don't let us fall out; make me happy, and let this be buried in oblivion. You know I hate oſtentation;
you know I do. Come, come, Honeywood, you know I always lov'd to be a friend, and not a patron. I beg this may make no kind of diſtance between us. Come, come, you and I muſt be more familiar—Indeed we muſt.

sp.speaker: Honeyw.
sp.p: Heavens! Can I ever repay ſuch friendſhip! Is there any way! Thou beſt of men, can I ever return the obligation?

sp.speaker: Lofty.
sp.p: A bagatelle, a mere bagatelle. But I ſee your heart is labouring to be grateful. You ſhall be grateful. It would be cruel to diſappoint you.

sp.speaker: Honeyw.
sp.p: How! Teach me the manner. Is there any way?

sp.speaker: Lofty.
sp.p: From this moment you're mine. Yes, my friend, you ſhall know it—I'm in love.

sp.speaker: Honeyw.
sp.p: And can I aſſiſt you?

sp.speaker: Lofty.
sp.p: Nobody ſo well.

sp.speaker: Honeyw.
sp.p: In what manner? I'm all impatience.

sp.speaker: Lofty.
sp.p: You ſhall make love for me.

sp.speaker: Honeyw.
sp.p: And to whom ſhall I ſpeak in your favour?

sp.speaker: Lofty.
sp.p: To a lady with whom you have great intereſt, I aſſure you. Miſs Richland.

sp.speaker: Honeyw.
sp.p: Miſs Richland!

sp.speaker: Lofty.
sp.p: Yes, Miſs Richland. She has ſtruckthe blow up to the hilt, in my boſom, by Jupiter.

sp.speaker: Honeyw.
sp.p: Heavens! was ever any thing more unfortunate! It is too much to be endur'd.

sp.speaker: Lofty.
sp.p: Unfortunate indeed! And yet I can endure it, till you have opened the affair to her for me. Between ourſelves, I think ſhe likes me. I'm not apt to boaſt, but I think ſhe does.

sp.speaker: Honeyw.
sp.p: Indeed! But do you know the perſon you apply to?

sp.speaker: Lofty.
sp.p: Yes, I know you are her friend and mine: that's enough. To you, therefore, I commit the ſucceſs of my paſſion. I'll ſay no more, let friendſhip do the reſt. I have only to add, that if at any time my little intereſt can be of ſervice—but, hang it, I'll make no promiſes—you know my intereſt is your's at any time. No apologies, my friend, I'll not be anſwered, it ſhall be ſo.

sp.speaker: Honeyw.
sp.p: Open, generous, unſuſpecting man! He little thinks that I love her too; and with ſuch an ardent paſſion!—But then it was ever but a vain and hopeleſs one. My torment, my perſecution, what ſhall I do! Love, friendſhip, a hopeleſs paſſion, a deſerving friend! Love, that has been my tormentor; a friend, that has, perhaps, diſtreſs'd himſelf, to ſerve me. It ſhall be ſo. Yes, I will diſcard the fondling hope from my boſom, and exert all my influence in his favour. And yet to ſee her in the poſſeſſion of another!—Inſupportable. But then to betray a generous, truſty friend!—Worſe, worſe, Yes, I'm reſolv'd. Let me but be the inſtrument of their happineſs, and then quit a country, where I muſt for ever deſpair of finding my own.

div.stage: Enter OLIVIA and GARNET, who carries a Milliner's Box.

sp.speaker: Olivia.
sp.p: Dear me, I wiſh this journey were over. No news of Jarvis yet? I believe the old peeviſh creature delays purely to vex me.

sp.speaker: Garnet.
sp.p: Why, to be ſure, Madam, I did hear him ſay, a little ſnubbing before marriage, would teach you to bear it the better afterwards.

sp.speaker: Olivia.
sp.p: To be gone a full hour, tho' he had only to get a bill changed in the city! How provoking!

sp.speaker: Garnet.
sp.p: I'll lay my life, Mr. Leontine, that had twice as much to do, is ſetting off by this time from his inn; and here you are left behind.

sp.speaker: Olivia.
sp.p: Well, let us be prepar'd for his coming, however. Are you ſure you have omitted nothing, Garnet?

sp.speaker: Garnet.
sp.p: Not a ſtick, madam—all's here. Yet I wiſh you could take the white and ſilver to be married in. It's the worſt luck in the world, in any thing but white. I knew one Bett Stubbs, of our town, was married in red; and, as ſure as eggs is eggs, the bridegroom and ſhe had a miff before morning.

sp.speaker: Olivia.
sp.p: No matter. I'm all impatience till we are out of the houſe.

sp.speaker: Garnet.
sp.p: Bleſs me, madam, I had almoſt forgot the wedding ring!—The ſweet little thing—I don't think it would go on my little finger. And what if I put in a gentleman's night cap, in caſe of neceſſity, madam? But here's Jarvis.

sp.speaker: Olivia.
sp.p: O, Jarvis, are you come at laſt? We have been ready this half hour. Now let's be going. Let us fly!

sp.speaker: Jarvis.
sp.p: Aye, to Jericho; for we ſhall have no going to Scotland this bout, I fancy.

sp.speaker: Olivia.
sp.p: How! What's the matter?

sp.speaker: Jarvis.
sp.p: Money, money, is the matter, Madam. We have got no money. What the plague do you ſend me of your fool's errand for? My maſter's bill upon the city is not worth a ruſh. Here it is, Mrs. Garnet may pin up her hair with it.

sp.speaker: Olivia.
sp.p: Undone! How could Honeywood ſerve us ſo! What ſhall we do? Can't we go without it?

sp.speaker: Jarvis.
sp.p: Go to Scotland without money! To Scotland without money! Lord how ſome people underſtand geography! We might as well ſet ſail for Patagonia upon a cork jacket.

sp.speaker: Olivia.
sp.p: Such a diſappointment! What a baſe inſincere man was your maſter, to ſerve us in this manner. Is this his good nature?

sp.speaker: Jarvis.
sp.p: Nay, don't talk ill of my maſter, Madam. I won't bear to hear any body talk ill of him but myſelf.

sp.speaker: Garnet.
sp.p: Bleſs us! now I think on't, Madam, you need not be under any uneaſineſs, I ſaw Mr. Leontine receive forty guineas from his father juſt before he ſet out, and he can't yet have left the inn. A ſhort letter will reach him there.

sp.speaker: Olivia.
sp.p: Well remember'd, Garnet; I'll write immediately. How's this! Bleſs me, my hand trembles ſo I can't write a word. Do you write, Garnet; and, upon ſecond thought it will be better from you.

sp.speaker: Garnet.
sp.p:
Truly, madam, I write and indite but poorly. I never was kute at my larning. But I'll do
what I can to pleaſe you. Let me ſee. All out of my own head, I ſuppoſe?

sp.speaker: Olivia.
sp.p: Whatever you pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Garnet.
sp.p: (Writing.) Muſter Croaker. Twenty guineas, Madam?

sp.speaker: Olivia.
sp.p: Ay, twenty will do.

sp.speaker: Garnet.
sp.p: At the bar of the Talbot till call'd for. Expedition—will be blown up.—All of a flame. Quick, diſpatch—Cupid, the little God of Love—I conclude it, madam, with Cupid, I love to ſee a love letter end like poetry.

sp.speaker: Olivia.
sp.p: Well, well, what you pleaſe, any thing. But how ſhall we ſend it? I can truſt none of the fervants of this family.

sp.speaker: Garnet.
sp.p: Odſo, Madam, Mr. Honeywood's butler is in the next room; he's a dear, ſweet man; he'll do any thing for me.

sp.speaker: Jarvis.
sp.p: He! the dog, he'll certainly commit ſome blunder. He's drunk and ſober ten times a day.

sp.speaker: Olivia.
sp.p: No matter. Fly, Garnet; any body we can truſt will do. [Exit Garnet.] Well, Jarvis, now we can have nothing more to interrupt us. You may take up the things, and carry them on to the inn. Have you no hands, Jarvis?

sp.speaker: Jarvis.
sp.p: Soft and fair, young lady. You, that are going to be married, think things can never be done too faſt: but we that are old, and know what we are about, muſt elope methodically, Madam.

sp.speaker: Olivia.
sp.p: Well, ſure, if my indiſcretions were to be done over again—

sp.speaker: Jarvis.
sp.p: My life for it you would do them ten times over.

sp.speaker: Olivia.
sp.p: Why will you talk ſo? If you knew how unhappy they make me—

sp.speaker: Jarvis.
sp.p: Very unhappy, no doubt: I was once juſt as unhappy when I was going to be married myſelf. I'll tell you a ſtory about that—

sp.speaker: Olivia.
sp.p: A ſtory! when I'm all impatience to be away. Was there ever ſuch a dilatory creature!—

sp.speaker: Jarvis.
sp.p:
Well, Madam, if we muſt march, why we will march; that's all. Tho', odds bobs we have ſtill
forgot one thing we ſhould never travel without—a caſe of good razors, and a box of ſhaving-powder. But no matter, I believe we ſhall be pretty well ſhaved in Scotland.

sp.speaker: Garnet.
sp.p: Undone, undone, Madam. Ah, Mr. Jarvis, you ſaid right enough. As ſure as death Mr. Honeywood's rogue of a drunken butler, drop'd the letter before he went ten yards from the door. There's old Croaker has juſt pick'd it up, and is this moment reading it to himſelf in the hall.

sp.speaker: Olivia.
sp.p: Unfortunate! We ſhall be diſcover'd.

sp.speaker: Garnet.
sp.p: No, Madam: don't be uneaſy, he can make neither head nor tail of it. To be ſure he looks as if he was broke looſe from Bedlam about it, but he can't find what it means for all that. O Lud, he is coming this way all in the horrors!

sp.speaker: Olivia.
sp.p: Then let us leave the houſe this inſtant, for fear he ſhould aſk farther queſtions. In the mean time, Garnet, do you write and ſend off juſt ſuch another.

sp.speaker: Croaker.
sp.p: Death and deſtruction! Are all the horrors of air, fire and water to be levelled only at me! Am I only to be ſingled out for gunpowder-plots, combuſtibles and conflagration! Here it is—An incendiary letter drop'd at my door. To Muſter Croaker, theſe, with ſpeed. Ay, ay, plain enough the direction: all in the genuine incendiary ſpelling, and as cramp as the devil. With ſpeed. O, confound your ſpeed. But let me read it once more.

Muſtar Croakar as ſone as yoew ſee this leve twenty gunnes at the bar of the Talboot tell caled for or yowe and yower experetion will be al blown up: Ah, but too plain. Blood and gunpowder in every line of it. Blown up! murderous dog! All blown up! Heavens! what have I and my poor family done, to be all blown up! (reads.) Our pockets are low, and money we muſt have. Ay, there's the reaſon; they'll
blow us up, becauſe they have got low pockets. (Reads.) It is but a ſhort time you have to conſider; for if this takes wind, the houſe will quickly be all of a flame. Inhuman monſters! blow us up, and then burn us. The earthquake at Liſbon was but a bonfire to it. (Reads.) Make quick diſpatch, and ſo no more at preſent. But may Cupid, the little God of Love, go with you wherever you go. The little God of Love! Cupid, the little God of Love go with me! Go you to the devil, you and your little Cupid together; I'm ſo frightned, I ſcarce know whether I ſit, ſtand, or go. Perhaps this moment I'm treading on lighted matches, blazing brimſtone and barrels of gunpowder. They are preparing to blow me up into the clouds. Murder! We ſhall be all burnt in our beds; we ſhall be all burnt in our beds.

sp.speaker: Miſs Rich.
sp.p: Lord, Sir, what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Croaker.
sp.p: Murder's the matter. We ſhall be a blown up in our beds before morning.

sp.speaker: Miſs Rich.
sp.p: I hope not, Sir.

sp.speaker: Croaker.
sp.p: What ſignifies what you hope, Madam, when I have a certificate of it here in my hand. Will nothing alarm my family! Sleeping and eating, ſleeping and eating is the only work from morning till night in my houſe. My inſenſible crew could ſleep, tho' rock'd by an earthquake; and fry beef ſteaks at a volcano.

sp.speaker: Miſs Rich.
sp.p: But, Sir, you have alarmed them ſo often already, we have nothing but earthquakes, famines, plagues and mad dogs from year's end to year's end. You remember, Sir, it is not above a month ago, you aſſur'd us of a conſpiracy among the bakers, to poiſon us in our bread; and ſo kept the whole family a week upon potatoes.

sp.speaker: Croaker.
sp.p:
And potatoes were too good for them. But why do I ſtand talking here with a girl, when I ſhould be facing the enemy without? Here, John, Nicodemus, ſearch the houſe. Look into the cellars, to ſee if there be any combuſtibles below; and above,
in the apartments, that no matches be thrown in at the windows. Let all the fires be put out, and let the engine be drawn out in the yard, to play upon the houſe in caſe of neceſſity.

sp.speaker: Miſs Rich.
sp.p: What can he mean by all this? Yet, why ſhould I enquire, when he alarms us in this manner almoſt every day! But Honeywood has deſired an interview with me in private. What can he mean; or, rather, what means this palpitation at his approach! It is the firſt time he ever ſhewed any thing in his conduct that ſeem'd particular. Sure he cannot mean to—but he's here.

sp.speaker: Honeyw.
sp.p: I preſum'd to ſolicit this interview, Madam, before I left town, to be permitted—

sp.speaker: Miſs Rich.
sp.p: Indeed! Leaving town, Sir—

sp.speaker: Honeyw.
sp.p: Yes, Madam; perhaps the kingdom. I have preſumed, I ſay, to deſire the favour of this interview—in order to diſcloſe ſomething which our long friendſhip prompts. And yet my fears—

sp.speaker: Miſs Rich.
sp.p: His fears! What are his fears to mine!
We have indeed been long acquainted, Sir; very long. If I remember, our firſt meeting was at the French ambaſſador's.—Do you recollect how you were pleas'd to rally me upon my complexion there?

sp.speaker: Honeyw.
sp.p: Perfectly, madam; I preſum'd to reprove you for painting: but your warmer bluſhes ſoon convinc'd the company, that the colouring was all from nature.

sp.speaker: Miſs Rich.
sp.p: And yet you only meant it, in your good natur'd way, to make me pay a compliment to myſelf. In the ſame manner you danc'd that night with the moſt aukward woman in company, becauſe you ſaw nobody elſe would take her out.

sp.speaker: Honeyw.
sp.p: Yes; and was rewarded the next night, by dancing with the fineſt woman in company, that every body wiſh'd to take out.

sp.speaker: Miſs Rich.
sp.p: Well, Sir, if you thought ſo then, I fear your judgment has ſince corrected the errors of a firſt impreſſion. We generally ſhew to moſt advantage at firſt. Our ſex are like poor tradeſmen, that put all their beſt goods to be ſeen at the windows.

sp.speaker: Honeyw.
sp.p: The firſt impreſſion, Madam, did indeed deceive me. I expected to find a woman with all the faults of conſcious flattered beauty. I expected to find her vain and inſolent. But every day has ſince taught me that it is poſſible to poſſeſs ſenſe without pride, and beauty without affectation.

sp.speaker: Miſs Rich.
sp.p: This, Sir, is a ſtyle very unuſual with Mr. Honeywood; and I ſhould be glad to know why he thus attempts to encreaſe that vanity, which his own leſſons taught me to deſpiſe.

sp.speaker: Honeyw.
sp.p: I aſk pardon, Madam. Yet, from our long friendſhip, I preſumed I might have ſome right to offer, without offence, what you may refuſe without offending.

sp.speaker: Miſs Rich.
sp.p: Sir! I beg you'd reflect; tho', I fear, I ſhall ſcarce have any power to refuſe a requeſt of yours; yet, you may be precipitate: conſider, Sir.

sp.speaker: Honeyw.
sp.p: I own my raſhneſs; but, as I plead the cauſe of friendſhip, of one who loves.—Don't be alarmed, Madam.—Who loves you with the moſt ardent paſſion; whoſe whole happineſs is placed in you—

sp.speaker: Miſs Rich.
sp.p: I fear, Sir, I ſhall never find whom you mean, by this deſcription of him.

sp.speaker: Honeyw.
sp.p: Ah, Madam, it but too plainly points him out. Tho' he ſhould be too humble himſelf to urge his pretenſions, or you too modeſt to underſtand them.

sp.speaker: Miſs Rich.
sp.p: Well; it would be affectation any longer to pretend ignorance; and, I will own, Sir, I have long been prejudiced in his favour. It was but natural to wiſh to make his heart mine, as he ſeem'd himſelf ignorant of its value.

sp.speaker: Honeyw.
sp.p:
I ſee ſhe always lov'd him (aſide). I find, Madam, you're already ſenſible of his worth, his
paſſion. How happy is my friend, to be the favourite of one with ſuch ſenſe to diſtinguiſh merit, and ſuch beauty to reward it.

sp.speaker: Miſs Rich.
sp.p: Your friend! Sir. What friend?

sp.speaker: Honeyw.
sp.p: My beſt friend—My friend Mr. Lofty, Madam.

sp.speaker: Miſs Rich.
sp.p: He, Sir!

sp.speaker: Honeyw.
sp.p: Yes, he Madam. He is, indeed, what your warmeſt wiſhes might have form'd him. And to his other qualities, he adds that of the moſt paſſionate regard for you.

sp.speaker: Miſs Rich.
sp.p: Amazement!—No more of this, I beg you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Honeyw.
sp.p: I ſee your confuſion, Madam, and know how to interpret it. And ſince I ſo plainly read the language of your heart, ſhall I make my friend happy, by communicating your ſentiments.

sp.speaker: Miſs Rich.
sp.p: By no means.

sp.speaker: Honeyw.
sp.p: Excuſe me; I muſt; I know you deſire it.

sp.speaker: Miſs Rich.
sp.p: Mr. Honeywood, let me tell you, that you wrong my ſentiments and yourſelf. When I firſt applied to your friendſhip, I expected advice and aſſiſtance; but now, Sir, I ſee that it is vain to expect happineſs from him, who has been ſo bad an oeconomiſt of his own; and that I muſt diſclaim his friendſhip, who ceaſes to be a friend to himſelf.

sp.speaker: Honeyw.
sp.p: How is this! ſhe has confeſſed ſhe lov'd him, and yet ſhe ſeemed to part in diſpleaſure. Can I have done any thing to reproach myſelf with? No; I believe not; yet, after all, theſe things ſhould not be done by a third perſon; I ſhould have ſpared her confuſion. My friendſhip carried me a little too far.

div.stage: Enter CROAKER, with the letter in his hand, and Mrs. CROAKER.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Croaker.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! And ſo, my dear, it's your ſupreme wiſh that I ſhould be quite wretched upon this occaſion? Ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Croaker.
sp.p: (Mimicking) Ha, ha, ha! and ſo my dear it's your ſupreme pleaſure to give me no better conſolation?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Croaker.
sp.p: Poſitively, my dear, what is this incendiary ſtuff and trumpery to me. Our houſe may travel thro' the air like the houſe of Loretto, for ought I care, If I'm to be miſerable in it.

sp.speaker: Croaker.
sp.p: Would to Heaven it were converted into an houſe of correction for your benefit. Have we not every thing to alarm us? Perhaps, this very moment the tragedy is beginning.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Croaker.
sp.p: Then let us reſerve our diſtreſs till the riſing of the curtain, or give them the money they want, and have done with them.

sp.speaker: Croaker.
sp.p: Give them my money!—And pray, what right have they to my money?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Croaker.
sp.p: And pray, what right then have you to my good humour?

sp.speaker: Croaker.
sp.p: And ſo your good humour adviſes me to part with my money? Why then, to tell your good humour a piece of my mind, I'd ſooner part with my wife. Here's Mr. Honeywood, ſee what he'll ſay to it. My dear Honeywood, look at this incendiary letter dropped at my door. It will freeze you with terror; and yet lovey here can read it—Can read it, and laugh.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Croaker.
sp.p: Yes, and ſo will Mr. Honeywood.

sp.speaker: Croaker.
sp.p: If he does, I'll ſuffer to be hanged the next minute in the rogue's place, that's all.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Croaker.
sp.p: Speak, Mr. Honeywood; is there any thing more fooliſh than my huſband's fright upon this occaſion?

sp.speaker: Honeyw.
sp.p: It would not become me to decide, Madam; but doubtleſs, the greatneſs of his terrors now, will but invite them to renew their villainy another time.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Croaker.
sp.p: I told you, he'd be of my opinion.

sp.speaker: Croaker.
sp.p:
How, Sir! do you maintain that I ſhould lie down under ſuch an injury, and ſhew, neither by
my tears, or complaints, that I have ſomething of the ſpirit of a man in me?

sp.speaker: Honeyw.
sp.p: Pardon me, Sir. You ought to make the loudeſt complaints, if you deſire redreſs. The ſureſt way to have redreſs, is to be earneſt in the purſuit of it.

sp.speaker: Croaker.
sp.p: Ay, whoſe opinion is he of now?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Croaker.
sp.p: But don't you think that laughing off our fears is the beſt way?

sp.speaker: Honeyw.
sp.p: What is the beſt, Madam, few can ſay; but I'll maintain it to be a very wiſe way.

sp.speaker: Croaker.
sp.p: But we're talking of the beſt. Surely the beſt way is to face the enemy in the field, and not wait till he plunders us in our very very bed-chamber.

sp.speaker: Honeyw.
sp.p: Why, Sir, as to the beſt, that—that's a very wiſe way too.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Croaker.
sp.p: But can any thing be more abſurd, than to double our diſtreſſes by our apprehenſions, and put it in the power of every low fellow, that can ſcrawl ten words of wretched ſpelling, to torment us?

sp.speaker: Honeyw.
sp.p: Without doubt, nothing more abſurd.

sp.speaker: Croaker.
sp.p: How! would it not be more abſurd to deſpiſe the rattle till we are bit by the ſnake?

sp.speaker: Honeyw.
sp.p: Without doubt, perfectly abſurd.

sp.speaker: Croaker.
sp.p: Then you are of my opinion?

sp.speaker: Honeyw.
sp.p: Entirely.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Croaker.
sp.p: And you reject mine?

sp.speaker: Honeyw.
sp.p: Heaven's forbid, Madam. No, ſure no reaſoning can be more juſt than yours. We ought certainly to dſepiſe malice if we cannot oppoſe it, and not make the incendiary's pen as fatal to our repoſe as the highwayman's piſtol.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Croaker.
sp.p: O! then you think I'm quite right?

sp.speaker: Honeyw.
sp.p: Perfectly right.

sp.speaker: Croaker.
sp.p: A plague of plagues, we can't be both right. I ought to be ſorry, or I ought to be glad. My hat muſt be on my head, or my hat muſt be off.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Croaker
sp.p: Certainly, in two oppoſite opinions, if one be perfectly reaſonable, the other can't be perfectly right.

sp.speaker: Honeyw.
sp.p: And why may not both be right, Madam: Mr. Croaker in earneſtly ſeeking redreſs, and you in waiting the event with good humour? Pray let me ſee the letter again. I have it. This letter requires twenty guineas to be left at the bar of the Talbot inn. If it be indeed an incendiary letter, what if you and I, Sir, go there; and, when the writer comes to be paid his expected booty, ſeize him?

sp.speaker: Croaker.
sp.p: My dear friend its the very thing; the very thing. While I walk by the door, you ſhall plant yourſelf in ambuſh near the bar; burſt out upon the miſcreant like a maſqued battery; extort a confeſſion at once, and ſo hang him up by ſurpriſe.

sp.speaker: Honeyw.
sp.p: Yes; but I would not chuſe to exerciſe too much ſeverity. It is my maxim, Sir, that crimes generally puniſh themſelves.

sp.speaker: Croaker.
sp.p: Well, but we may upbraid him a little, I ſuppoſe? (Ironically.)

sp.speaker: Honeyw.
sp.p: Ay, but not puniſh him too rigidly.

sp.speaker: Croaker.
sp.p: Well, well, leave that to my own benevolence.

sp.speaker: Honeyw.
sp.p: Well, I do: but remember that univerſal benevolence is the firſt law of nature.

sp.speaker: Croaker.
sp.p: Yes; and my univerſal benevolence will hang the dog, if he had as many necks as a hydra.

div.head: ACT THE FIFTH.

sp.speaker: Olivia.
sp.p: Well, we have got ſafe to the inn, however. Now, if the poſt-chaiſe were ready—

sp.speaker: Jarvis.
sp.p: The horſes are juſt finiſhing their oats; and, as they are not going to be married, they chuſe to take their own time.

sp.speaker: Olivia.
sp.p: You are for ever giving wrong motives to my impatience.

sp.speaker: Jarvis.
sp.p: Be as impatient as you will, the horſes muſt take their own time; beſides, you don't conſider, we have got no anſwer from our fellow traveller yet. If we hear nothing from Mr. Leontine, we have only one way left us.

sp.speaker: Olivia.
sp.p: What way?

sp.speaker: Jarvis.
sp.p: The way home again.

sp.speaker: Olivia.
sp.p: Not ſo. I have made a reſolution to go, and nothing ſhall induce me to break it.

sp.speaker: Jarvis.
sp.p: Ay; reſolutions are well kept when they jump with inclination. However, I'll go haſten things without. And I'll call too at the bar to ſee if any thing ſhould be left for us there. Don't be in ſuch a plaguy hurry, Madam, and we ſhall go the faſter, I promiſe you.

sp.speaker: Landlady.
sp.p: What! Solomon; why don't you move? Pipes and tobacco for the Lamb there.—Will no body anſwer? To the Dolphin; quick. The Angel has been outrageous this half hour. Did your ladyſhip call, Madam?

sp.speaker: Olivia.
sp.p: No, Madam.

sp.speaker: Landlady.
sp.p: I find, as you're for Scotland, Madam—But, that's no buſineſs of mine; married, or not married, I aſk no queſtions. To be ſure, we had a ſweet little couple ſet off from this two days ago for the ſame place. The Gentleman, for a Taylor, was, to be ſure, as fine a ſpoken taylor, as ever blew froth from a full pot. And the young lady ſo baſhful, it was near half an hour before we could get her to finiſh a pint of raſberry between us.

sp.speaker: Olivia.
sp.p: But this gentleman and I are not going to be married, I aſſure you.

sp.speaker: Landlady.
sp.p: May be not. That's no buſineſs of mine; for certain, Scotch marriages ſeldom turn out. There was of my own knowledge, Miſs Macfag, that married her father's footman.—Alack-a-day, ſhe and her huſband ſoon parted, and now keep ſeparate cellars in Hedge-Lane.

sp.speaker: Olivia.
sp.p: A very pretty picture of what lies before me.

sp.speaker: Leont.
sp.p: My dear Olivia, my anxiety till you were out of danger, was too great to be reſiſted. I could not help coming to ſee you ſet out, tho' it expoſes us to a diſcovery.

sp.speaker: Olivia.
sp.p: May every thing you do prove as fortunate. Indeed, Leontine, we have been moſt cruelly diſappointed. Mr. Honeywood's bill upon the city, has, it ſeems been proteſted, and we have been utterly at a loſs how to proceed.

sp.speaker: Leont.
sp.p: How! An offer of his own too. Sure, he could not mean to deceive us.

sp.speaker: Olivia.
sp.p: Depend upon his ſincerity; he only miſtook the deſire for the power of ſerving us. But let us think no more of it. I believe the poſt-chaiſe is ready by this.

sp.speaker: Landlady.
sp.p:
Not quite yet! and, begging your ladyſhip's pardon, I don't think your ladyſhip quite ready for the poſt-chaiſe. The north road is a cold place, Madam. I have a drop in the houſe of as pretty
raſberry as ever was tipt over tongue. Juſt a thimble full to keep the wind off your ſtomach. To be ſure, the laſt couple we had here, they ſaid it was a perfect noſegay. Ecod, I ſent them both away as good natur'd—Up went the blinds, round went the wheels, and drive away poſt-boy, was the word.

sp.speaker: Croaker.
sp.p: Well, while my friend Honeywood is upon the poſt of danger at the bar, it muſt be my buſineſs to have an eye about me here. I think I know an incendiary's look; for, wherever the devil makes a purchaſe, he never fails to ſet his mark. Ha! who have we here? My ſon and daughter! What can they be doing here!

sp.speaker: Landlady.
sp.p: I tell you, Madam, it will do you good; I think I know by this time what's good for the north road. It's a raw night, Madam.—Sir—

sp.speaker: Leont.
sp.p: Not a drop more, good Madam. I ſhould now take it as a greater favour, if you haſten the horſes, for I am afraid to be ſeen myſelf.

sp.speaker: Landlady.
sp.p: That ſhall be done. Wha, Solomon! are you all dead there? Wha, Solomon, I ſay.

sp.speaker: Olivia.
sp.p: Well; I dread, leſt an expedition begun in fear, ſhould end in repentance.—Every moment we ſtay increaſes our danger, and adds to my apprehenſions.

sp.speaker: Leont.
sp.p: There's no danger, truſt me, my dear; there can be none: if Honeywood has acted with honour, and kept my father, as he promiſed, in employment till we are out of danger, nothing can interrupt our journey.

sp.speaker: Olivia.
sp.p: I have no doubt of Mr. Honeywood's ſincerity, and even his deſires to ſerve us. My fears are from your father's ſuſpicions. A mind ſo diſpoſed to be alarmed without a cauſe, will be but too ready when there's a reaſon.

sp.speaker: Leont.
sp.p:
Why, let him, when we are out of his power. But, believe me, Olivia, you have no great
reaſon to dread his reſentment. His repining temper, as it does no manner of injury to himſelf, ſo will it never do harm to others. He only frets to keep himſelf employed, and ſcolds for his private amuſement.

sp.speaker: Olivia.
sp.p: I don't know that; but, I'm ſure, on ſome occaſions, it makes him look moſt ſhockingly.

sp.speaker: Croaker.
sp.p: (Diſcovering himſelf) How does he look now?—How does he look now?

sp.speaker: Olivia.
sp.p: Ah!

sp.speaker: Leont.
sp.p: Undone.

sp.speaker: Croaker.
sp.p: How do I look now? Sir, I am your very humble ſervant. Madam, I am your's. What, you are going off, are you? Then, firſt, if you pleaſe, take a word or two from me with you before you go. Tell me firſt where you are going? and when you have told me that, perhaps, I ſhall know as little as I did before.

sp.speaker: Leont.
sp.p: If that be ſo, our anſwer might but increaſe your diſpleaſure, without adding to your information.

sp.speaker: Croaker.
sp.p: I want no information from you, puppy: and you too, good Madam, what anſwer have you got. Eh (a cry without, ſtop him). I think I heard a noiſe. My friend, Honeywood, without—has he ſeized the incendiary? Ah, no, for now I heard no more on't.

sp.speaker: Leont.
sp.p: Honeywood, without! Then, Sir, it was Mr. Honeywood that directed you hither?

sp.speaker: Croaker.
sp.p: No, Sir, it was Mr. Honeywood conducted me hither.

sp.speaker: Leont.
sp.p: Is it poſſible?

sp.speaker: Croaker.
sp.p: Poſſible! Why, he's in the houſe now, Sir. More anxious about me, than my own ſon, Sir.

sp.speaker: Leont.
sp.p: Then, Sir, he's a villian.

sp.speaker: Croaker.
sp.p: How, ſirrah! a villian, becauſe he takes moſt care of your father? I'll not bear it. I tell you I'll not bear it. Honeywood is a friend to the family, and I'll have him treated as ſuch.

sp.speaker: Leont.
sp.p: I ſhall ſtudy to repay his friendſhip as it deſerves.

sp.speaker: Croaker.
sp.p: Ah, rogue, If you knew how earneſtly he entered into my griefs, and pointed out the means to detect them, you would love him as I do. (A cry without ſtop him) Fire and fury! they have ſeized the incendiary: they have the villian, the incendiary in view. Stop him, ſtop an incendiary, a murderer; ſtop him.

sp.speaker: Olivia.
sp.p: Oh, my terrors! What can this new tumult mean?

sp.speaker: Leont.
sp.p: Some new mark, I ſuppoſe, of Mr Honeywood's ſincerity. But we ſhall have ſatisfaction: he ſhall give me inſtant ſatisſaction.

sp.speaker: Olivia.
sp.p: It muſt not be, my Leontine, if you value my eſteem, or my happineſs. Whatever be our fate, let us not add guilt to our misfortunes—Conſider that our innocence will ſhortly be all we have left us. You muſt forgive him.

sp.speaker: Leont.
sp.p: Forgive him! Has he not in every inſtance betrayed us? Forced me to borrow money from him, which appears a mere trick to delay us: promiſed to keep my father engaged till we were out of danger, and here brought him to the very ſcene of our eſcape?

sp.speaker: Olivia.
sp.p: Don't be precipitate. We may yet be miſtaken.

div.stage: Enter POSTBOY, dragging in JARVIS: HONEYWOOD entering ſoon after.

sp.speaker: Poſtboy.
sp.p: Ay, maſter, we have him faſt enough. Here is the incendiary dog. I'm entitled to the reward; I'll take my oath I ſaw him aſk for the money at the bar, and then run for it.

sp.speaker: Honeyw.
sp.p: Come, bring him along. Let us ſee him. Let him learn to bluſh for his crimes. (Diſcovering his miſtake). Death! what's here! Jarvis, Leontine, Olivia! What can all this mean?

sp.speaker: Jarvis.
sp.p: Why, I'll tell you what it means: that I was an old fool, and that you are my maſter—that's all.

sp.speaker: Honeyw.
sp.p: Confuſion.

sp.speaker: Leont.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, I find you have kept your word with me. After ſuch baſeneſs, I wonder how you can venture to ſee the man you have injured.

sp.speaker: Honeyw.
sp.p: My dear Leontine, by my life, my honour—

sp.speaker: Leont.
sp.p: Peace, peace, for ſhame; and do not continue to aggravate baſeneſs by hypocriſy. I know you Sir, I know you.

sp.speaker: Honeyw.
sp.p: Why, wont you hear me! By all that's juſt, I knew not—

sp.speaker: Leont.
sp.p: Hear you, Sir! to what purpoſe? I now ſee through all your low arts; your ever complying with every opinion; your never refuſing any requeſt; your friendſhip as common as a proſtitute's favours, and as fallacious; all theſe, Sir, have long been contemptible to the world, and are now perfectly ſo to me.

sp.speaker: Honeyw.
sp.p: Ha! contemptible to the world! That reaches me. (Aſide.)

sp.speaker: Leont.
sp.p: All the ſeeming ſincerity of your profeſſions I now find were only allurements to betray; and all your ſeeming regret for their conſequences, only calculated to cover the cowardice of your heart. Draw, villain!

sp.speaker: Croaker.
sp.p: Where is the villain? Where is the incendiary? (ſeizing the poſt-boy.) Hold him faſt, the dog; he has the gallows in his face. Come, you dog, confeſs; confeſs all, and hang yourſelf.

sp.speaker: Poſt-Boy.
sp.p: Zounds! Maſter, what do you throttle me for?

sp.speaker: Croaker.
sp.p: (Beating him.) Dog, do you reſiſt; do you reſiſt?

sp.speaker: Poſt-Boy.
sp.p: Zounds! Maſter, I'm not he; there's the man that we thought was the rogue, and turns out to be one of the company.

sp.speaker: Croaker.
sp.p: How!

sp.speaker: Honeyw.
sp.p: Mr. Croaker, we have all been under a ſtrange miſtake here; I find there is nobody guilty; it was all an error; entirely an error of our own.

sp.speaker: Croaker.
sp.p: And I ſay, Sir, that you're in an error; for there's guilt and double guilt, a plot, a damn'd jeſuitical peſtilential plot, and I muſt have proof of it.

sp.speaker: Honeyw.
sp.p: Do but hear me.

sp.speaker: Croaker.
sp.p: What, you intend to bring'em off, I ſuppoſe; I'll hear nothing.

sp.speaker: Honeyw.
sp.p: Madam, you ſeem at leaſt calm enough to hear reaſon.

sp.speaker: Olivia.
sp.p: Excuſe me.

sp.speaker: Honeyw.
sp.p: Good Jarvis, let me then explain it to you.

sp.speaker: Jarvis.
sp.p: What ſignifies explanations, when the thing is done?

sp.speaker: Honeyw.
sp.p: Will nobody hear me? Was there ever ſuch a ſet, ſo blinded by paſſion and prejudice! (To the Poſt-Boy.) My good friend, I believe you'll be ſurprized when I aſſure you—

sp.speaker: Poſt-Boy.
sp.p: Sure me nothing—I'm ſure of nothing but a good beating.

sp.speaker: Croaker.
sp.p: Come then, you, Madam, if you ever hope for any favour or forgiveneſs, tell me ſincerely all you know of this affair.

sp.speaker: Olivia.
sp.p: Unhappily, Sir, I'm but too much the cauſe of your ſuſpicions: you ſee before you, Sir, one that with falſe pretences has ſtept into your family to betray it: not your daughter—

sp.speaker: Croaker.
sp.p: Not my daughter!

sp.speaker: Olivia.
sp.p: Not your daughter—but a mean deceiver—who—ſupport me, I cannot—

sp.speaker: Honeyw.
sp.p: Help, ſhe's going, give her air.

sp.speaker: Croaker.
sp.p: Ay, ay; take the young woman to the air, I would not hurt a hair of her head, whoſe ever daughter ſhe may be—not ſo bad as that neither.

sp.speaker: Croaker.
sp.p:
Yes, yes, all's out; I now ſee the whole affair: my ſon is either married, or going to be ſo,
to this lady, whom he impoſed upon me as his ſiſter. Ay, certainly ſo; and yet I don't find it afflicts me ſo much as one might think. There's the advantage of fretting away our misfortunes beforehand, we never feel them when they come.

div.stage: Enter Miſs RICHLAND and SIR WILLIAM.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: But how do you know, Madam, that my nephew intends ſetting off from this place?

sp.speaker: Miſs Rich.
sp.p: My maid aſſured me he was come to this inn, and my own knowledge of his intending to leave the kingdom, ſuggeſted the reſt. But what do I ſee, my guardian here before us! Who, my dear Sir, could have expected meeting you here; to what accident do we owe this pleaſure?

sp.speaker: Croaker.
sp.p: To a fool, I believe.

sp.speaker: Miſs Rich.
sp.p: But to what purpoſe did you come?

sp.speaker: Croaker.
sp.p: To play the fool.

sp.speaker: Miſs Rich.
sp.p: But with whom?

sp.speaker: Croaker.
sp.p: With greater fools than myſelf.

sp.speaker: Miſs Rich.
sp.p: Explain.

sp.speaker: Croaker.
sp.p: Why, Mr. Honeywood brought me here, to do nothing now I am here; and my ſon is going to be married to I don't know who that is here; ſo now you are as wiſe as I am.

sp.speaker: Miſs Rich.
sp.p: Married! to whom, Sir?

sp.speaker: Croaker.
sp.p: To Olivia; my daughter, as I took her to be; but who the devil ſhe is, or whoſe daughter ſhe is, I know no more than the man in the moon.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Then, Sir, I can inform you; and, tho' a ſtranger, yet you ſhall find me a friend to your family: it will be enough at preſent, to aſſure you, that, both in point of birth and fortune, the young lady is at leaſt your ſon's equal. Being left by her father, Sir James Woodville—

sp.speaker: Croaker.
sp.p: Sir James Woodville! What, of the Weſt?

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p:
Being left by him, I ſay, to the care of a mercenary wretch, whoſe only aim was to ſecure her fortune to himſelf, ſhe was ſent into France, under pretence of education; and there every art
was tried to fix her for life in a convent, contrary to her inclinations. Of this I was informed upon my arrival at Paris; and, as I had been once her father's friend, I did all in my power to fruſtrate her guardian's baſe intentions. I had even meditated to reſcue her from his authority, when your ſon ſtept in with more pleaſing violence, gave her liberty, and you a daughter.

sp.speaker: Croaker.
sp.p: But I intend to have a daughter of my own chuſing, Sir. A young lady, Sir, whoſe fortune, by my intereſt with thoſe that have intereſt, will be double what my ſon has a right to expect. Do you know Mr. Lofty, Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Yes, Sir; and know that you are deceived in him. But ſtep this way, and I'll convince you.
sp.stage: [Croaker and Sir William ſeem to confer.

sp.speaker: Honeyw.
sp.p: Obſtinate man, ſtill to perſiſt in his outrage! Inſulted by him, deſpis'd by all, I now begin to grow contemptible, even to myſelf. How have I ſunk by too great an aſſiduity to pleaſe! How have I overtax'd all my abilities, leſt the approbation of a ſingle fool ſhould eſcape me! But all is now over; I have ſurvived my reputation, my fortune, my friendſhips, and nothing remains henceforward for me but ſolitude and repentance.

sp.speaker: Miſs Rich.
sp.p: Is it true, Mr. Honeywood, that you are ſetting off, without taking leave of your friends? The report is, that you are quitting England. Can it be?

sp.speaker: Honeyw.
sp.p: Yes, Madam; and tho' I am ſo unhappy as to have fallen under your diſpleaſure, yet, thank Heaven, I leave you to happineſs; to one who loves you, and deſerves your love; to one who has power to procure you affluence, and generoſity to improve your enjoyment of it.

sp.speaker: Miſs Rich.
sp.p: And are you ſure, Sir, that the gentleman you mean is what you deſcribe him?

sp.speaker: Honeyw.
sp.p: I have the beſt aſſurances of it, his ſerving me. He does indeed deſerve the higheſt happineſs, and that is in your power to confer. As for me! weak and wavering as I have been, obliged by all, and incapable of ſerving any, what happineſs can I find but in ſolitude? What hope but in being forgotten?

sp.speaker: Miſs Rich.
sp.p: A thouſand! to live among friends that eſteem you, whoſe happineſs it will be to be permitted to oblige you.

sp.speaker: Honeyw.
sp.p: No, Madam; my reſolution is fix'd. Inferiority among ſtrangers is eaſy; but among thoſe that once were equals, inſupportable. Nay, to ſhew you how far my reſolution can go, I can now ſpeak with calmneſs of my former follies, my vanity, my diſſipation, my weakneſs. I will even confeſs, that, among the number of my other preſumptions, I had the inſolence to think of loving you. Yes, Madam, while I was pleading the paſſion of another, my heart was tortur'd with its own. But it is over, it was unworthy our friendſhip, and let it be forgotten.

sp.speaker: Miſs Rich.
sp.p: You amaze me!

sp.speaker: Honeyw.
sp.p: But you'll forgive it, I know you will; ſince the confeſſion ſhould not have come from me even now, but to convince you of the ſincerity of my intention of—never mentioning it more.

sp.speaker: Miſs Rich.
sp.p: Stay, Sir, one moment—Ha! he here—

sp.speaker: Lofty.
sp.p: Is the coaſt clear? None but friends? I have followed you here with a trifling piece of intelligence: but it goes no farther, things are not yet ripe for a diſcovery. I have ſpirits working at a certain board; Your affair at the treaſury will be done in leſs than—a thouſand years, Mum!

sp.speaker: Miſs Rich.
sp.p: Sooner, Sir, I ſhould hope.

sp.speaker: Lofty.
sp.p: Why, yes, I believe it may, if it falls into proper hands, that know where to puſh and where to parry; that know how the land lies—eh, Honeywood.

sp.speaker: Miſs Rich.
sp.p: It is ſallen into yours.

sp.speaker: Lofty.
sp.p: Well, to keep you no longer in ſuſpenſe, your thing is done. It is done, I ſay—that's all. I have juſt had aſſurances from Lord Neverout, that the claim has been examined, and found admiſſible. Quietus is the word, Madam.

sp.speaker: Honeyw.
sp.p: But how! his Lordſhip has been at Newmarket theſe ten days.

sp.speaker: Lofty.
sp.p: Indeed! Then Sir Gilbert Gooſe muſt have been moſt damnably miſtaken. I had it of him.

sp.speaker: Miſs Rich.
sp.p: He! why Sir Gilbert and his family have been in the country this month.

sp.speaker: Lofty.
sp.p: This month! It muſt certainly be ſo—Sir Gilbert's Letter did come to me from Newmarket, ſo that he muſt have met his Lordſhip there; and ſo it came about. I have his letter about me, I 'll read it to you. (Taking out a large bundle.) That's from Paoli of Corſica, that from the Marquis of Squilachi.—Have you a mind to ſee a letter from Count Poniatowſki, now King of Poland—Honeſt Pon—
O, Sir, what are you here too? I'll tell you what, honeſt friend, if you have not abſolutely delivered my letter to Sir William Honeywood, you may return it. The thing will do without him.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: Sir, I have delivered it, and muſt inform you, it was received with the moſt mortifying contempt.

sp.speaker: Croaker.
sp.p: Contempt! Mr. Lofty, what can that mean?

sp.speaker: Lofty.
sp.p: Let him go on, let him go on, I ſay. You'll find it come to ſomething preſently.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, I believe you'll be amazed, if, after waiting ſome time in the anti-chamber, after being ſurveyed with inſolent curioſity by the paſſing ſervants, I was at laſt aſſured, that Sir William Honeywood knew no ſuch perſon, and I muſt certainly have been impoſed upon.

sp.speaker: Lofty.
sp.p: Good; let me die, very good. Ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Croaker.
sp.p: Now, for my life, I can't find out half the goodneſs of it.

sp.speaker: Lofty.
sp.p: You can't. Ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Croaker.
sp.p: No, for the ſoul of me; I think it was as confounded a bad anſwer, as ever was ſent from one private gentleman to another.

sp.speaker: Lofty.
sp.p: And ſo you can't find out the force of the meſſage? Why I was in the houſe at that very time. Ha! ha! It was I that ſent that very anſwer to my own letter. Ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Croaker.
sp.p: Indeed! How! why!

sp.speaker: Lofty.
sp.p: In one word, things between Sir William and me muſt be behind the curtain. A party has many eyes. He ſides with Lord Buzzard, I ſide with Sir Gilbert Gooſe. So that unriddles the myſtery.

sp.speaker: Croaker.
sp.p: And ſo it does indeed, and all my ſuſpicions are over.

sp.speaker: Lofty.
sp.p: Your ſuſpicions! What then you have been ſuſpecting, you have been ſuſpecting, have you? Mr. Croaker, you and I were friends, we are friends no longer. Never talk to me. It's over; I ſay, it's over.

sp.speaker: Croaker.
sp.p: As I hope for your favour, I did not mean to offend. It eſcaped me. Don't be diſcompoſed.

sp.speaker: Lofty.
sp.p: Zounds, Sir, but I am diſcompoſed, and will be diſcompoſed. To be treated thus! Who am I! Was it for this I have been dreaded both by inns and outs! Have I been libelled in the Gazetteer, and praiſed in the St. James's; have I been chaired at Wildman's, and a ſpeaker at Merchant Taylor's Hall; have I had my hand to addreſſes, and my head in the print-ſhops, and talk to me of ſuſpects!

sp.speaker: Croaker.
sp.p: My dear Sir, be pacified. What can you have but aſking pardon?

sp.speaker: Lofty.
sp.p: Sir, I will not be pacified—Suſpects! Who am I! To be uſed thus, have I paid court to men in favour to ſerve my friends, the Lords of the Treaſury, Sir William Honeywood, and the reſt of the gang, and talk to me of ſuſpects! Who am I, I ſay, who am I!

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p:
Since, Sir, you're ſo preſſing for an anſwer, I'll tell you who you are. A gentleman, as well acquainted with politics, as with men in power;
as well acquainted with perſons of faſhion, as with modeſty; with Lords of the Treaſury, as with truth; and with all, as you are with Sir William Honeywood. I am Sir William Honeywood.

sp.speaker: Croaker.
sp.p: Sir William Honeywood!

sp.speaker: Honeyw.
sp.p: Aſtoniſhment! my uncle!

sp.speaker: Lofty.
sp.p: So then my confounded genius has been all this time only leading me up to the garret, in order to fling me out of the window.

sp.speaker: Croaker.
sp.p: What, Mr. Importance, and are theſe your works? Suſpect you! You who have been dreaded by the inns and outs: you who have had your hand to addreſſes, and your head ſtuck up in print-ſhops. If your were ſerved right, you ſhould have your head ſtuck up in the pillory.

sp.speaker: Lofty.
sp.p: Ay, ſtick it where you will, for, by the Lord, it cuts but a very poor figure where it ſticks at preſent.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Well, Mr. Croaker, I hope you now ſee how incapable this gentleman is of ſerving you, and how little Miſs Richland has to expect from his influence.

sp.speaker: Croaker.
sp.p: Ay, Sir, too well I ſee it, and I can't but ſay I have had ſome boding of it theſe ten days. So I'm reſolved, ſince my ſon has placed his affections on a lady of moderate fortune, to be ſatisfied with his choice, and not run the hazard of another Mr. Lofty, in helping him to a better.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: I approve your reſolution, and here they come, to receive a confirmation of your pardon and conſent.

div.stage: Enter Mrs. CROAKER, JARVIS, LEONTINE, OLIVIA.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Croaker.
sp.p: Where's my huſband! Come, come, lovely, you muſt forgive them. Jarvis here has been to tell me the whole affair; and, I ſay, you muſt forgive them. Our own was a ſtolen match, you know, my dear; and we never had any reaſon to repent of it.

sp.speaker: Croaker.
sp.p: I wiſh we could both ſay ſo: however, this gentleman, Sir William Honeywood, has been beforehand with you, in obtaining their pardon. So, if the two poor fools have a mind to marry, I think, we can tack them together without croſſing the Tweed for it.

sp.speaker: Leont.
sp.p: How bleſt, and unexpected! What, what can we ſay to ſuch goodneſs! But our future obedience ſhall be the beſt reply. And, as for this gentleman, to whom we owe—

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Excuſe me, Sir, if I interrupt your thanks, as I have here an intereſt that calls me. (Turning to Honeywood.) Yes, Sir, you are ſurpriſed to ſee me; and I own that a deſire of correcting your follies led me hither. I ſaw, with indignation, the errors of a mind that only ſought applauſe from others; that eaſineſs of diſpoſition, which, tho' inclin'd to the right, had not courage to condemn the wrong. I ſaw with regret thoſe ſplendid errors, that ſtill took name from ſome neighbouring duty. Your charity, that was but injuſtice; your benevolence, that was but weakneſs; and your friendſhip but credulity. I ſaw, with regret, great talents and extenſive learning, only employed to add ſprightlineſs to error, and encreaſe your perplexities. I ſaw your mind with a thouſand natural charms: but the greatneſs of its beauty ſerved only to heighten my pity for its proſtitution.

sp.speaker: Honeyw.
sp.p: Ceaſe to upbraid me, Sir; I have for ſome time but too ſtrongly felt the juſtice of your repoaches. But there is one way ſtill left me. Yes, Sir, I have determined, this very hour, to quit for ever a place where I have made myſelf the voluntary ſlave of all; and to ſeek among ſtrangers that fortitude which may give ſtrength to the mind, and marſhal all its diffipated virtues. Yet, ere I depart, permit me to ſolicit favour for this gentleman; who, notwithſtanding what has happened, has laid me under the moſt ſignal obligations. Mr. Lofty—

sp.speaker: Lofty.
sp.p:
Mr. Honeywood, I'm reſolv'd upon a reformation, as well as you. I now begin to find, that
the man who firſt invented the art of ſpeaking truth was a much cunninger fellow than I thought him. And to prove that I deſign to ſpeak truth for the future, I muſt now aſſure you, that you owe your late enlargement to another; as, upon my ſoul, I had no hand in the matter. So now, if any of the company has a mind for preferment, he may take my place. I'm determined to reſign.

sp.speaker: Honeyw.
sp.p: How have I been deceived!

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: No, Sir, you have been obliged to a kinder, fairer friend for that favour. To Miſs Richland. Would ſhe complete our joy, and make the man ſhe has honoured by her friendſhip happy in her love, I ſhould then forget all, and be as bleſt as the welfare of my deareſt kinſman can make me.

sp.speaker: Miſs Rich.
sp.p: After what is paſt, it would be but affectation to pretend to indifference. Yes, I will own an attachment, which, I find, was more than friendſhip. And if my intreaties cannot alter his reſolution to quit the country; I will even try, if my hand has not power to detain him.

sp.speaker: Honeyw.
sp.p: Heavens! how can I have deſerved all this? How expreſs my happineſs, my gratitude! A moment, like this, over-pays an age of apprehenſion.

sp.speaker: Croaker.
sp.p: Well, now I ſee content in every face; but Heaven ſend we be all better this day three months.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Henceforth, nephew, learn to reſpect yourſelf. He who ſeeks only for applauſe from without, has all his happineſs in another's keeping.

sp.speaker: Honeyw.
sp.p:
Yes, Sir, I now too plainly perceive my errors. My vanity, in attempting to pleaſe all, by fearing to offend any. My meanneſs in approving
folly, leſt fools ſhould diſapprove. Henceforth, therefore, it ſhall be my ſtudy to reſerve my pity for real diſtreſs; my friendſhip for true merit, and my love for her, who firſt taught me what it is to be happy.

div.head: EPILOGUE,
div.l: AS puffing quacks ſome caitiff wretch procure
To ſwear the pill, or drop, has wrought a cure;
Thus on the ſtage, our play-wrights ſtill depend
For Epilogues and Prologues on ſome friend,
Who knows each art of coaxing up the town,
And make full many a bitter pill go down.
Conſcious of this, our bard has gone about,
And teaz'd each rhyming friend to help him out.
An Epilogue, things can't go on without it;
It cou'd not fail, wou'd you but ſet about it.
Young man, cries one (a bard laid up in clover)
Alas, young man, my writing days are over;
Let boys play tricks, and kick the ſtraw, not I;
Your brother Doctor there, perhaps, may try.
What Il dear Sir, the Doctor interpoſes,
What plant my thiſtle, Sir, among his roſes!
No, no, I've other conteſts to maintain;
To-night I head our troops at Warwick-Lane.
Go, aſk your manager—Who, me? your pardon;
Thoſe things are not our fort at Covent-Garden.
Our Author's friends, thus plac'd at happy diſtance,
Gives him good words indeed, but no aſſiſtance.
As ſome unhappy wight, at ſome new play,
At the Pit door ſtands elbowing away,
While oft, with many a ſmile, and many a ſhrug,
He eyes the centre, where his friends ſit ſnug,
His ſimpering friends, with pleaſure in their eyes,
Sink as he ſinks, and as he riſes riſe:
He nods, they nod; he cringes, they grimace;
But not a ſoul will budge to give him place.
Since then, unhelp'd, our bard muſt now conform
To 'bide the pelting of this pittileſs ſtorm,
Blame where you muſt, be candid where you can,
And view with favour, the Good-natur'd Man.
